Pittman D.D. Toole J.J. Kriz R.W. Aldape R.A. Hewick R.M. Kaufman R.J. Mann K.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 4846-4850Crossref PubMed Scopus (340) Google Scholar, 7Jenny R.J. Tracy P.B. Mann K.G. Bloom A.L. Forbes C.D. Thomas D.P. Tuddenham E.G.D. Haemostasis and Thrombosis. Churchill Livingstone Inc., New York1994: 456-476Google Scholar). Upon limited proteolysis by thrombin at Arg709, Arg1018, and Arg1545, the B-domain is removed from the remaining part of FV, which forms procoagulant FVa (8Esmon C.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 964-973Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 9Nesheim M.E. Mann K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 1326-1334Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 10Suzuki K. Dahlback B. Stenflo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 6556-6564Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Keller F.G. Ortel T.L. Quinn-Allen M.A. Kane W.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 4118-4124Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). FVa is a heterodimer of the 105-kDa heavy chain (A1-A2) and the 71/74-kDa light chain (A3-C1-C2), the two chains being noncovalently associated (8Esmon C.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 964-973Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 9Nesheim M.E. Mann K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 1326-1334Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A theoretical model of the A-domains of FVa has been created (12Villoutreix B.O. Dahlback B. Protein Sci. 1998; 7: 1317-1325Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). The model proposes the A-domains to be in close contact with each other and oriented in a triangular fashion. This arrangement is believed to remain essentially unchanged after activation and B-domain release (12Villoutreix B.O. Dahlback B. Protein Sci. 1998; 7: 1317-1325Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). After cleavage of FV at Arg709, the B-domain remains attached to the A3-domain. Cleavages at both Arg709 and Arg1018 release a 71-kDa peptide fragment of the B-domain. The remaining part of the B-domain (150 kDa) is released upon cleavage at Arg1545 (9Nesheim M.E. Mann K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 1326-1334Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 10Suzuki K. Dahlback B. Stenflo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 6556-6564Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Keller F.G. Ortel T.L. Quinn-Allen M.A. Kane W.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 4118-4124Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). The Arg709 and Arg1018 cleavages are kinetically favored (10Suzuki K. Dahlback B. Stenflo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 6556-6564Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Keller F.G. Ortel T.L. Quinn-Allen M.A. Kane W.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 4118-4124Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 14Monkovic D.D. Tracy P.B. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 1118-1128Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar, 15Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1998; 80: 92-98Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar), whereas the cleavage at Arg1545has been shown to be most important for generation of fully activated FVa (11Keller F.G. Ortel T.L. Quinn-Allen M.A. Kane W.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 4118-4124Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Although thrombin is the most important activator of FV, the three cleavages discussed can also be performed by FXa (13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar,14Monkovic D.D. Tracy P.B. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 1118-1128Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar, 16Foster W.B. Nesheim M.E. Mann K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 13970-13977Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, an FXa-sensitive site has been identified at Arg1765 (13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar).Recombinant FV variants having the three cleavage sites eliminated separately or in combination by mutagenesis to Gln or Ile have recently been described (13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 15Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1998; 80: 92-98Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). We have now used these FV variants to elucidate how each of the cleavages affects the ability of FV to interact with FXa using both a kinetic approach and a direct binding assay for the phospholipid-bound interaction between FXa and FV/FVa. The results provide insights into the FV and FXa interaction and shed light on the molecular events that are associated with the activation process (i.e. the release of the B-domain and exposure of binding sites for FXa).DISCUSSIONInvestigations of the FV-FXa interaction are of particular importance as the activation of prothrombin plays a central role in blood coagulation. The binding of FXa to Va is crucial for the formation of a fully active prothrombinase complex, and the interaction is the target of careful control, which is a prerequisite for health. Thus, the formation of the prothrombinase complex depends on the activation of FV by thrombin or FXa, whereas down-regulation of the biological activity of the complex is the result of proteolytic modification of FVa exerted by the protein C system (3Rosing J. Tans G. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1997; 78: 427-433Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar, 31Dahlback B. J. Lab. Clin. Med. 1999; 133: 415-422Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar). Although the formation of the prothrombinase complex is crucial in the coagulation, little is known about the structure-function relationships of the complex. More is known about the homologous tenase complex, which, due to the fact that structural pathology of the tenase complex causes hemophilia A, has been the subject of intense investigations (32Mertens K. Celie P.H. Kolkman J.A. Lenting P.J. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1999; 82: 209-217Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar).Using recombinant FV having one or more of the thrombin cleavage sites eliminated by mutagenesis, we have now been able to investigate the importance of each cleavage site for the creation of the FXa-binding site and for the expression of prothrombinase activity. In comparison, FXa bound to the fully activated FVa molecule with an apparentK d of 0.2 nm and to intact FV with an apparent K d of 10 nm. The results demonstrated the importance of all three cleavages (i.e. at Arg709, Arg1018, and Arg1545) in FV for expression of the FXa cofactor activity in the activation of prothrombin. The Arg1545 cleavage had the largest impact on the FVa-FXa interaction and in itself yielded a 20-fold increased affinity of the interaction. This is in agreement with a recent report on cathepsin G and elastase proteolysis of FV, which indicated cleavage at Arg1545 to facilitate FXa binding (27Camire R.M. Kalafatis M. Tracy P.B. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 11896-11906Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar) The Arg709 cleavage contributed less to the affinity of the interaction than that at Arg1545. Thus, a 5-fold increased affinity of the FXa binding was observed when the FV variant that could only be cleaved at Arg709 (RIQ) was compared with those that contained no cleavage site (i.e. QIQ and QIQQQ). It was noteworthy that the Arg1018 cleavage in itself resulted in a 3-fold increase in affinity of the FVa-FXa interaction, implying that the Arg1018 cleavage is important in the activation process. The cleavage at Arg1018 has previously been shown to facilitate the Arg1545 cleavage (33Marquette K.A. Pittman D.D. Kaufman R.J. Blood. 1995; 86: 3026-3034Crossref PubMed Google Scholar).Single chain FV interacts poorly with FXa and therefore has little or no procoagulant activity (Fig.7 A). FV activation intermediates may play important roles as cofactors to FXa during the early phase of the coagulation process (Fig. 7 B). The Arg709 and the Arg1018 cleavages are kinetically favored over the Arg1545 cleavage and require very low thrombin concentrations (10Suzuki K. Dahlback B. Stenflo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 6556-6564Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Keller F.G. Ortel T.L. Quinn-Allen M.A. Kane W.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 4118-4124Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 14Monkovic D.D. Tracy P.B. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 1118-1128Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar, 15Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1998; 80: 92-98Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). This suggests that these cleavages occur early in coagulation and that they may be important for the FV-FXa interaction before the clot is formed, when the thrombin concentration is still low (34Kalafatis M. Xue J. Lawler C.M. Mann K.G. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 6538-6545Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 35Kumar R. Beguin S. Hemker H.C. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1994; 72: 713-721Crossref PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). The Arg1545 cleavage presumably occurs late in the clotting process after sufficient thrombin has been generated to cleave this site. In addition, the Arg1545 cleavage generates the most potent FVa, giving the thrombin generation an additional boost late in the clotting process (Fig. 7 C). This may be important for the activation of FXIII and subsequent cross-linking of the fibrin network. In addition, it may be involved in increasing the concentration of thrombin within the clot.Figure 7Schematic models demonstrating that the gradual release of the B-domain leads to exposure of the FXa binding site. A, intact FV circulates as procofactor with poor procoagulant properties. The FV QIQ variant, being resistant to thrombin cleavage, appeared to have an apparent K dfor FXa in the 10 nm range when assembled in the prothrombinase complex. B, the cleavages at 709 and 1018 occur at very low thrombin concentrations and result in removal of the N-terminal part of the B-domain. The FV variant RRQ, representing a molecule that can only be cleaved at 709 and 1018, appeared to have an apparent K d of 1.2 nm for FXa, which is 8-fold lower than the apparent K d for QIQ.C, the cleavage at 1545 requires high thrombin concentrations, indicating that it occurs later in the coagulation process when sufficient thrombin has been generated. The cleavage at 1545 releases the B-domain, and fully activated FVa is formed. The interaction of fully activated FVa with FXa had an apparentK d of ∼0.2 nm.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT)FXa has been reported to cleave FV at all three thrombin cleavage sites (i.e. at Arg709, Arg1018, and Arg1545). The physiological importance of the FXa-mediated activation of FV is not known. An additional FXa cleavage site is present at Arg1765 (13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Moreover, we have observed that FXa cleaves at yet another position in the A3-domain, at Arg1761. 2M. Steen and B. Dahlbäck, unpublished data. However, the cleavages at Arg1761 and Arg1765do not contribute to the FVa-FXa interaction, because the FV variants QIQ and QIQQQ demonstrate identical affinities for FXa in both the prothrombinase assay and in the direct binding assay.The location of the FXa binding site in FVa has not been characterized in detail. Residues 493–506 (36Heeb M.J. Kojima Y. Hackeng T.M. Griffin J.H. Protein Sci. 1996; 5: 1883-1889Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar) and 311–325 (37Kojima Y. Heeb M.J. Gale A.J. Hackeng T.M. Griffin J.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 14900-14905Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar) in the A2-domain of FVa have based on peptide binding studies been suggested to be important for FXa binding. Furthermore, the C-terminal region of the heavy chain of FVa, comprising residues 684–709, has been suggested to be involved in FXa binding (28Bakker H.M. Tans G. Thomassen M.C. Yukelson L.Y. Ebberink R. Hemker H.C. Rosing J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20662-20667Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This region is probably more exposed after the cleavage at Arg709, a conclusion that is in agreement with our present results. The major increase in FXa binding affinity observed after the Arg1545 cleavage is compatible with the involvement of the light chain of FVa in the binding of FXa and the exposure of the binding site after release of the B-domain. The involvement of the light chain in the interaction with FXa has previously been suggested based on an inhibitory effect on the FXa interaction of a monoclonal antibody directed against the A3-domain (34Kalafatis M. Xue J. Lawler C.M. Mann K.G. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 6538-6545Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). In FVIII, which is homologous to FV, a FIXa-binding site has been located to residues 1811–1818 in the A3-domain. The homologous region in FV comprising residues 1677–1683 could potentially be part of the binding site for FXa, a site that in intact FV may be covered by the C-terminal region of the B-domain.Our data show that the release of the B-domain is not associated with improved interaction with prothrombin, suggesting that the B-domain does not conceal any binding site for prothrombin. The knowledge about the structure-function relationships of the interaction between prothrombin and FV/FVa is scarce. In prothrombin, the first kringle domain has been suggested to carry a site important for the interaction with FVa (38Deguchi H. Takeya H. Gabazza E.C. Nishioka J. Suzuki K. Biochem. J. 1997; 321: 729-735Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar), whereas the second kringle domain has been shown to interact with both FVa and FXa during the assembly of the prothrombinase complex (39Esmon C.T. Jackson C.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1974; 249: 7791-7797Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 40Church W.R. Ouellette L.A. Messier T.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 8384-8391Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In FVa, the C-terminal part of the heavy chain has been suggested to be important for the interaction with prothrombin (28Bakker H.M. Tans G. Thomassen M.C. Yukelson L.Y. Ebberink R. Hemker H.C. Rosing J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 20662-20667Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, although this region should be more accessible after cleavage of FV at Arg709, there is no difference in K m for prothrombin activation before or after cleavage at Arg709. The K dvalues obtained from the functional studies, which included prothrombin, were in most cases lower than those obtained in the direct binding experiments. Whether this was due to specific stimulation of the interaction between FXa and FVa by the presence of prothrombin, as has been reported earlier (41Billy D. Willems G.M. Hemker H.C. Lindhout T. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 26883-26889Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar), or just due to experimental differences is not known.Little is known about the three-dimensional structure and the function of the B-domain of FV. The A- and C-domains of FV and FVIII share important sequence identities (∼30 and 40%, respectively), but there is no sequence similarity between the two B-domains. The A-domains of the light and heavy chains of FV have been suggested to form a globular structure from which the B-domain projects as an extended rod having extensive contacts with the solvent (42Fowler W.E. Fay P.J. Arvan D.S. Marder V.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 7648-7652Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). The B-domain carries 25 potential glycosylation sites, the many negative charges of which may inhibit the interaction between FV and FXa. It has been shown that removal of the negative charges of sialic acid residues on the oligosaccharides by treatment with neuraminidase results in enhanced FVa activity (43Bruin T. Sturk A. ten Cate J.W. Cath M. Eur. J. Biochem. 1987; 170: 305-310Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar), which could be the result of improved FXa binding to FV. Hence, the function of the B-domain could be to both sterically and electrostatically inhibit binding of FXa to the intact FV molecule. This function of the B-domain would then be crucial in prohibiting premature coagulation.In conclusion, we have shown the binding site for FXa on FV to be exposed as a result of FV activation and B-domain release, whereas the interaction with prothrombin was unaffected by the activation process. Intact FV was demonstrated to weakly interact with FXa, and the conversion to fully active FVa was associated with a 50-fold increased affinity of FXa for FVa. All three activation cleavages of FV (i.e. at Arg709, Arg1018, and Arg1545) were found to increase the affinity of FV for FXa. The Arg709 and Arg1018 cleavages, which occur at very low thrombin concentrations, are presumably important during in the initial phase of coagulation. The Arg1545 cleavage, which is less sensitive to thrombin, has the greatest impact on the FXa affinity and seems to be important at a later stage in the coagulation. The inhibitory effect of the B-domain on the FV-FXa interaction could be exerted by both steric and electrostatic means and may be important to prevent the association of FXa with intact FV, thus avoiding premature thrombin generation. Chem. 1979; 254: 964-973Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 9Nesheim M.E. Mann K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 1326-1334Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A theoretical model of the A-domains of FVa has been created (12Villoutreix B.O. Dahlback B. Protein Sci. 1998; 7: 1317-1325Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). The model proposes the A-domains to be in close contact with each other and oriented in a triangular fashion. This arrangement is believed to remain essentially unchanged after activation and B-domain release (12Villoutreix B.O. Dahlback B. Protein Sci. 1998; 7: 1317-1325Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). After cleavage of FV at Arg709, the B-domain remains attached to the A3-domain. Cleavages at both Arg709 and Arg1018 release a 71-kDa peptide fragment of the B-domain. The remaining part of the B-domain (150 kDa) is released upon cleavage at Arg1545 (9Nesheim M.E. Mann K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 1326-1334Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 10Suzuki K. Dahlback B. Stenflo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 6556-6564Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Keller F.G. Ortel T.L. Quinn-Allen M.A. Kane W.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 4118-4124Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). The Arg709 and Arg1018 cleavages are kinetically favored (10Suzuki K. Dahlback B. Stenflo J. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 6556-6564Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 11Keller F.G. Ortel T.L. Quinn-Allen M.A. Kane W.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 4118-4124Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 14Monkovic D.D. Tracy P.B. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 1118-1128Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar, 15Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1998; 80: 92-98Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar), whereas the cleavage at Arg1545has been shown to be most important for generation of fully activated FVa (11Keller F.G. Ortel T.L. Quinn-Allen M.A. Kane W.H. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 4118-4124Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Although thrombin is the most important activator of FV, the three cleavages discussed can also be performed by FXa (13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar,14Monkovic D.D. Tracy P.B. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 1118-1128Crossref PubMed Scopus (206) Google Scholar, 16Foster W.B. Nesheim M.E. Mann K.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 13970-13977Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, an FXa-sensitive site has been identified at Arg1765 (13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Recombinant FV variants having the three cleavage sites eliminated separately or in combination by mutagenesis to Gln or Ile have recently been described (13Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1997; 247: 12-20Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 15Thorelli E. Kaufman R.J. Dahlback B. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1998; 80: 92-98Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). We have now used these FV variants to elucidate how each of the cleavages affects the ability of FV to interact with FXa using both a kinetic approach and a direct binding assay for the phospholipid-bound interaction between FXa and FV/FVa. The results provide insights into the FV and FXa interaction and shed light on the molecular events that are associated with the activation process (i.e. the release of the B-domain and exposure of binding sites for FXa). DISCUSSIONInvestigations of the FV-FXa interaction are of particular importance as the activation of prothrombin plays a central role in blood coagulation. The binding of FXa to Va is crucial for the formation of a fully active prothrombinase complex, and the intera

l-Carnitine is essential for β-oxidation of fatty acids in mitochondria. Bacterial metabolic pathways are used for the production of this medically important compound. Here, we report the first detailed functional characterization of the caiT gene product, a putative transport protein whose function is required forl-carnitine conversion in Escherichia coli. ThecaiT gene was overexpressed in E. coli, and the gene product was purified by affinity chromatography and reconstituted into proteoliposomes. Functional analyses with intact cells and proteoliposomes demonstrated that CaiT is able to catalyze the exchange of l-carnitine for γ-butyrobetaine, the excreted end product of l-carnitine conversion in E. coli, and related betaines. Electrochemical ion gradients did not significantly stimulate l-carnitine uptake. Analysis ofl-carnitine counterflow yielded an apparent externalK m of 105 μm and a turnover number of 5.5 s−1. Contrary to related proteins, CaiT activity was not modulated by osmotic stress. l-Carnitine binding to CaiT increased the protein fluorescence and caused a red shift in the emission maximum, an observation explained by ligand-induced conformational alterations. The fluorescence effect was specific for betaine structures, for which the distance between trimethylammonium and carboxyl groups proved to be crucial for affinity. Taken together, the results suggest that CaiT functions as an exchanger (antiporter) for l-carnitine and γ-butyrobetaine according to the substrate/product antiport principle. l-Carnitine is essential for β-oxidation of fatty acids in mitochondria. Bacterial metabolic pathways are used for the production of this medically important compound. Here, we report the first detailed functional characterization of the caiT gene product, a putative transport protein whose function is required forl-carnitine conversion in Escherichia coli. ThecaiT gene was overexpressed in E. coli, and the gene product was purified by affinity chromatography and reconstituted into proteoliposomes. Functional analyses with intact cells and proteoliposomes demonstrated that CaiT is able to catalyze the exchange of l-carnitine for γ-butyrobetaine, the excreted end product of l-carnitine conversion in E. coli, and related betaines. Electrochemical ion gradients did not significantly stimulate l-carnitine uptake. Analysis ofl-carnitine counterflow yielded an apparent externalK m of 105 μm and a turnover number of 5.5 s−1. Contrary to related proteins, CaiT activity was not modulated by osmotic stress. l-Carnitine binding to CaiT increased the protein fluorescence and caused a red shift in the emission maximum, an observation explained by ligand-induced conformational alterations. The fluorescence effect was specific for betaine structures, for which the distance between trimethylammonium and carboxyl groups proved to be crucial for affinity. Taken together, the results suggest that CaiT functions as an exchanger (antiporter) for l-carnitine and γ-butyrobetaine according to the substrate/product antiport principle. betaine/carnitine/choline transporter 2-(N-morpholino)ethanesulfonic acid l-Carnitine (R-(−)-3-hydroxy-4-trimethylaminobutyrate) is essential for transport of activated fatty acids across the inner mitochondrial membrane via the carnitine/acylcarnitine exchange protein (1Bremer J. Physiol. Rev. 1983; 63: 1420-1480Crossref PubMed Scopus (1356) Google Scholar, 2Rebouche C.J. Seim H. Annu. Rev. Nutr. 1998; 18: 39-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (299) Google Scholar). Bacteria use l-carnitine in different ways (3Kleber H.-P. FEMS Microbiol. Lett. 1997; 147: 1-9Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). For example, Escherichia coli and other enterobacteria accumulate the betaine as a compatible solute under osmotic stress (4Jung H. Jung K. Kleber H.-P. J. Basic Microbiol. 1990; 30: 409-413Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar,5Sleator R.D. Hill C. FEMS Microbiol. Rev. 2002; 26: 49-71Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, these bacteria take up l-carnitine under anaerobic growth conditions if no other electron acceptors or glucose is present and convert it into γ-butyrobetaine (4-trimethylaminobutyrate), the excreted end product of the pathway (6Seim H. Ezold R. Kleber H.-P. Strack E. Z. Allg. Mikrobiol. 1980; 20: 591-594Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Crotonobetaine (4-trimethylaminocrotonate) is formed as an intermediate and probably serves as an electron acceptor under these growth conditions (7Seim H. Löster H. Kleber H.-P. Acta Biol. Med. Ger. 1982; 41: 1009-1018PubMed Google Scholar, 8Jung K. Jung H. Kleber H.-P. J. Basic Microbiol. 1987; 27: 131-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar) (cf. also Fig. 8). This pathway is particularly interesting, as it can be reverted and used for the enantioselective production of l-carnitine (9Jung H. Jung K. Kleber H.-P. Adv. Biochem. Eng. Biotechnol. 1993; 50: 21-44PubMed Google Scholar,10Obon J.M. Maiquez J.R. Canovas M. Kleber H.-P. Iborra J.L. Appl. Microbiol. Biotechnol. 1999; 51: 760-764Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). As a prerequisite of biotransformation, substrate and product must be transported across the cell membrane. To date, only very little is known about the mechanism underlyingl-carnitine uptake and γ-butyrobetaine excretion. Early studies using a wild-type E. coli strain (O44K74) showed that the cells possess an active, carrier-mediated uptake system specific for l-carnitine (11Jung H. Jung K. Kleber H.-P. J. Basic Microbiol. 1990; 30: 507-514Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). Transport was not assigned to a specific gene product. Therefore, we focus here on the elucidation of the transport mechanism forl-carnitine and related betaines in E. coli. The E. coli genes responsible for carnitine conversion have been cloned and sequenced (12Eichler K. Bourgis F. Buchet A. Kleber H.-P. Mandrand-Berthelot M.A. Mol. Microbiol. 1994; 13: 775-786Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar, 13Eichler K. Buchet A. Bourgis F. Kleber H.-P. Mandrand-Berthelot M.A. J. Basic Microbiol. 1995; 35: 217-227Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 14Eichler K. Schunck W.H. Kleber H.-P. Mandrand-Berthelot M.A. J. Bacteriol. 1994; 176: 2970-2975Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The genes are organized in two divergent operons, one of which is the caiTABCDE operon. The products of the caiB and caiA genes, carnitine dehydratase and crotonobetaine reductase, have been characterized in previous studies (15Elssner T. Hennig L. Frauendorf H. Haferburg D. Kleber H.-P. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 10761-10769Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar, 16Jung H. Jung K. Kleber H.-P. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1989; 1003: 270-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 17Preusser A. Wagner U. Elssner T. Kleber H.-P. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1999; 1431: 166-178Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar, 18Roth S. Jung K. Jung H. Hommel R.K. Kleber H.-P. Antonie Leeuwenhoek. 1994; 65: 63-69Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). Furthermore, the product of thecaiT gene was proposed to function as a transporter based on sequence comparison and hydropathy profile analysis (13Eichler K. Buchet A. Bourgis F. Kleber H.-P. Mandrand-Berthelot M.A. J. Basic Microbiol. 1995; 35: 217-227Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). ThecaiT gene encodes a highly hydrophobic protein of 504 amino acids, which probably form 12 membrane-spanning domains (Fig.1). CaiT displays similarity to the glycine betaine uptake system OpuD from Bacillus subtilis, the choline transporter BetT from E. coli, BetP fromCorynebacterium glutamicum, and a BetT-like protein fromHaemophilus influenza (19Peter H. Burkovski A. Krämer R. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 5229-5234Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 20Kappes R.M. Kempf B. Bremer E. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 5071-5079Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). They form a small family of transporters, the betaine/carnitine/choline transporter (BCCT)1 family (Transport Protein Database TC 2.A.15). 2Available at tcdb.ucsd.edu/tcdb/tcfamilybrowse.php?tcname=2.A.15. 2Available at tcdb.ucsd.edu/tcdb/tcfamilybrowse.php?tcname=2.A.15. Proteins of this family share the common functional feature of transporting molecules with a quaternary ammonium group (R-N+(CH3)3). Some of these transporters have been shown to utilize electrochemical ion gradients (H+, Na+) for substrate accumulation. In addition, some members of the family are osmotically regulated and share hydrophilic extensions at the N and/or C termini (19Peter H. Burkovski A. Krämer R. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 5229-5234Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 20Kappes R.M. Kempf B. Bremer E. J. Bacteriol. 1996; 178: 5071-5079Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 22Peter H. Burkovski A. Krämer R. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 2567-2574Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar,23Rübenhagen R. Ronsch H. Jung H. Krämer R. Morbach S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 735-741Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). This study represents the first detailed analysis of CaiT function. For this purpose, CaiT was purified and reconstituted into proteoliposomes. Functional analyses with intact cells and proteoliposomes demonstrated that CaiT is able to catalyze the exchange of l-carnitine for γ-butyrobetaine and related betaines, whereas electrochemical ion gradients do not significantly stimulate l-carnitine uptake. Analysis of CaiT fluorescence revealed ligand-induced conformational alterations. The fluorescence approach was used to obtain information on the substrate specificity of the transporter. l-[methyl-14C]Carnitine (53 μCi/μmol) and horseradish peroxidase-conjugated sheep anti-mouse IgG were purchased from Amersham Biosciences. E. coli JM109 (endA1 recA1 gyrA96 thi hsdR17 supE44 λ − relA1 Δ(lac-proAB)/F′ traD36 proAB + lacI q lacZΔM15) (24Yanisch-Perron C. Vieira J. Messing J. Gene (Amst.). 1985; 33: 103-119Crossref PubMed Scopus (11410) Google Scholar) served as carrier for the plasmids described. Biol. 1993; 229: 268-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar) was employed for transport measurements. E. coli BL21(DE3) pLysS (F− ompT hasdS B(rB−mB−) gal dcm (DE3) pLysS (camR)) (Novagen) was used for overexpression of the caiT gene from the T7 promoter in plasmid pTcaiT. Plasmid pT7-5 (26Tabor S. Richardson C.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 1074-1078Crossref PubMed Scopus (2436) Google Scholar) was used for cloning and expression of the caiT gene. ThecaiT gene was amplified from a preparation of genomic DNA from E. coli by PCR with Taq DNA polymerase. PCR primers were designed to introduce BamHI andHindIII restriction sites at the 5′- and 3′-ends of the gene, respectively. The new sites uniquely flank a 1.5-kb DNA fragment containing the caiT gene with its ATG start and TAA stop codons. The PCR product was partially digested with BamHI and HindIII, and the isolated 1.5-kb DNA fragment was ligated into plasmid pT7-5 digested with the same two restriction enzymes, yielding plasmid pTcaiT. The integrity of the cloned sequence was confirmed by DNA sequencing. To facilitate attachment of a nucleotide sequence encoding the FLAG epitope (DYKDDDDK) and a His6 tag (ASSHHHHHH), aPstI restriction site was introduced before the stop codon at the 3′-end of caiT. The resulting plasmid, pTcaiT(PstI), was digested with XmaI and PstI, and a 1.8-kb DNA fragment containing the caiT gene was isolated. In parallel, a PstI site was inserted between the 3′-end of theputP gene and the FLAG-His6 tag in plasmid pTputPFH (27Jung H. Tebbe S. Schmid R. Jung K. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 11083-11088Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). After digestion with XmaI andPstI, a 2.6-kb DNA fragment comprising the nucleotide sequence of plasmid pT7-5 and the FLAG-His6 tag was isolated and ligated with the 1.8-kb fragment from plasmid pTcaiT(PstI), yielding plasmid pTcaiTFH. E. coli WG389 cells harboring plasmid pTcaiT (or its derivatives) were grown aerobically in LB medium (28Miller J.H. A Short Course in Bacterial Genetics: A Laboratory Manual and Handbook for Escherichia coli and Related Bacteria. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1992: 102Google Scholar) containing 200 mml-proline and 100 μg/ml ampicillin at 37 °C, and expression was initiated by addition of 0.5 mmisopropyl-β-d-thiogalactopyranoside in the middle of the exponential growth phase. After further growth for 2 h, cells were harvested by centrifugation, washed with 100 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.5) and 2 mm β-mercaptoethanol, and immediately used for transport assays. E. coli BL21(DE3) pLysS cells containing the corresponding plasmids were grown as described for strain WG389, except that the LB medium contained 100 μg/ml ampicillin and 34 μg/ml chloramphenicol. In the middle of the exponential growth phase, gene expression was induced by addition of 0.3 mm isopropyl-β-d-thiogalactopyranoside, and incubation was continued for 3 h. Cells were harvested and washed as described above. Cells were frozen and kept at −80 °C until used. The amount of CaiT in E. coli WG389 and BL21(DE3) pLysS membranes was estimated by immunoblotting with mouse anti-FLAG IgG raised against the FLAG epitope at the carboxyl terminus of the protein, followed by incubation with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated sheep anti-mouse IgG as described (29Quick M. Tebbe S. Jung H. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 239: 732-736Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Inverted membrane vesicles ofE. coli BL21(DE3) pLysS containing CaiTFH (CaiT with the FLAG epitope and a His6 tag attached to the C terminus) were prepared by passage of the cell suspension through a Sorvall RF1 Ribi refrigerated cell fractionator, followed by low speed centrifugation at 12,000 × g for 30 min at 4 °C to remove unbroken cells. Membranes were collected by centrifugation at 230,000 × g for 90 min at 4 °C, washed with 50 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.5) and 2 mmβ-mercaptoethanol, resuspended in the same buffer, and stored at −80 °C. For solubilization of CaiTFH, inverted membrane vesicles were diluted into 50 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 8.0) to yield a protein concentration of 5 mg/ml. The membrane suspension was supplemented with 2 mm β-mercaptoethanol and 10% glycerol. Dodecyl β-d-maltoside was added stepwise to yield a final concentration of 1.5% (w/v) while stirring on ice. After additional stirring for 30 min, the sample was centrifuged at 230,000 × g for 20 min. The supernatant was supplemented with 10 mm imidazole and 300 mmNaCl and incubated with Ni2+-nitrilotriacetic acid (1 ml of resin/45 mg of membrane protein) for 45 min with gentle shaking at 4 °C. The resin had been pre-equilibrated with 25 bed volumes of 50 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 8.0), 300 mmNaCl, 10 mm imidazole, 2 mmβ-mercaptoethanol, 10% (v/v) glycerol, and 0.04% (w/v) dodecyl β-d-maltoside (buffer A). The protein-resin complex was then packed into a column, and unbound protein was removed by washing with buffer A until the absorbance at 280 nm returned to the base line. Subsequently, the resin was washed with 20 bed volumes of buffer A containing 30 mm imidazole to remove loosely bound protein. CaiTFH was eluted from the column with 200 mm imidazole in buffer A. Purified CaiTFH was reconstituted into preformed liposomes that were prepared from acetone/ether-washed E. coli phospholipids as described (27Jung H. Tebbe S. Schmid R. Jung K. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 11083-11088Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). Prior to reconstitution, the liposomes were destabilized by addition of 0.12% (w/v) Triton X-100. Destabilized liposomes were mixed with purified protein at ratios of 100:1 (for transport measurements) or 20:1 (w/w) (for fluorescence measurements) and incubated at room temperature under gentle agitation for 10 min. Detergent was removed by adding Bio-Beads SM-2 pretreated as described (30Holloway P.W. Anal. Biochem. 1973; 53: 304-308Crossref PubMed Scopus (638) Google Scholar) at wet weight bead/detergent ratios of 5:1 and 10:1 (w/w) for Triton X-100 and dodecyl β-d-maltoside, respectively. After 1 h of incubation at room temperature, fresh Bio-Beads were added, and incubation was continued for an additional hour. After the third addition of Bio-Beads, incubation was continued overnight at 4 °C. Bio-Beads were removed by filtration on glass silk, and the turbid proteoliposome suspension was dialyzed two times against 100 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.5) and 2 mmβ-mercaptoethanol at 4 °C. Proteoliposomes were concentrated by centrifugation at 300,000 × g for 45 min and stored in liquid N2. Freshly grownE. coli WG389 cells transformed with either pTcaiT or pT7-5 were resuspended in 100 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.5), 2 mm β-mercaptoethanol, and 5 mm MgCl2 (resuspension buffer), thereby adjusting the total protein concentration to 0.35 mg/ml.l-[methyl-14C]Carnitine uptake was measured at substrate concentrations from 2 to 50 μm at 25 °C. For analysis of the Na+ dependence of transport, 50 mm NaCl was added immediately prior to addition ofl-[methyl-14C]carnitine. The medium osmolality was raised by addition of 0.4 m NaCl or 0.6 m sucrose where indicated. For exchange experiments, cells were concentrated in resuspension buffer (7 mg of total cell protein/ml) and equilibrated with the corresponding trimethylammonium compound (10 mm) at 4 °C overnight. The resulting cell suspension was diluted 200-fold into resuspension buffer containingl-[methyl-14C]carnitine (53 Ci/mol) at a concentration of 4.7 μm. In the case of counterflow experiments (cells preloaded with 10 mml-carnitine), this yielded a final externall-carnitine concentration of 54.7 μm. Incubation was carried out at 25 °C, and transport was terminated at different time points by addition of 100 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 6.0) and 100 mm LiCl (stop buffer) and rapid filtration as described (29Quick M. Tebbe S. Jung H. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 239: 732-736Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Wilson T.H. Kaback H.R. Methods Enzymol. 1986; 125: 429-452Crossref PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar).l-[methyl-14C]Carnitine uptake was measured with proteoliposomes in 100 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.5), 2 mm β-mercaptoethanol, and 5 mm MgSO4 (buffer B). Ion-dependent transport was started by 200-fold dilution of aliquots of the proteoliposome suspension (2 μl) into buffer containing 100 mm Tris/Mes (pH 6.0), 2 mm β-mercaptoethanol, 5 mm MgSO4, and 0.2 μmvalinomycin (creation of ΔμH+) or 100 mm Tris/Mes (pH 7.5), 2 mm β-mercaptoethanol, 5 mm MgSO4, 0.2 μm valinomycin, and 50 mm NaCl (creation of ΔμNa+). The buffers containedl-[methyl-14C]carnitine at concentrations varying between 2 and 50 μm. For exchange experiments, the proteoliposome suspension was 10-fold diluted; the desired trimethylammonium compound was added to a final concentration of 10 mm; and the suspension was frozen in liquid nitrogen. After thawing, the samples were extruded through a 400-nm filter to obtain unilamellar proteoliposomes of homogeneous size (32Mayer L.D. Hope M.J. Cullis P.R. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1986; 858: 161-168Crossref PubMed Scopus (1558) Google Scholar). The proteoliposomes were concentrated by centrifugation and adjusted to a protein concentration of 1–2 mg/ml. Aliquots (2 μl) of the proteoliposome suspension were diluted into 400 μl of buffer B.l-[methyl-14C]Carnitine (53 Ci/mol) was added at a concentration of 4.7 μm. In thel-carnitine counterflow experiments (preloading with 10 mml-carnitine), this yielded a final externall-carnitine concentration of 54.7 μm. To analyze the effect of N-ethylmaleimide on transport, the proteoliposomes (in buffer without β-mercaptoethanol) were preincubated with the sulfhydryl reagent (2 mm final concentration) at 25 °C for 10 min, and the reaction was stopped by addition of 5 mm β-mercaptoethanol. Transport assays were carried out at 25 °C (if not indicated otherwise) and terminated at a given time by quenching of the reaction with 2.5 ml ice-cold stop buffer and immediate filtration using Millipore GSTF 02500 filters (0.2-μm pore size). All measurements were performed a minimum of three times. Fluorescence was measured using an SLM-AMINCO 4800 spectrofluorometer at 25 °C. The excitation wavelength was set to 290 nm, and emission was recorded between 310 and 370 nm with slit widths of 4 nm. Measurements were carried out on samples containing 80 μg of reconstituted CaiTFH/ml of buffer B. The lipid/protein ratio of the proteoliposomes was 20:1. The diameter of the proteoliposomes was adjusted to 100 nm by extrusion through a corresponding filter. For measurements with solubilized CaiTFH, 80 μg of protein/ml of buffer (100 mm potassium phosphate buffer (pH 7.5), 2 mm β-mercaptoethanol, 5 mmMgSO4, and 0.04% dodecyl β-d-maltoside) were used. Ligands were added at the indicated concentrations, and the mixture was incubated for 10 min at 25 °C prior to measurement. All fluorescence data were corrected for a buffer blank and for dilution effects. The fluorescence intensity measured at 338 nm was used to calculate the apparent affinity constant K 0.5, reflecting the ligand concentration causing a half-maximum change in CaiTFH fluorescence. For this purpose, the data were fitted with the analysis program SigmaPlot (Jandel Scientific) using Equation 1, ΔF/F=(ΔF/Fmax)·[L]/(K0.5+[L])Equation 1 where ΔF is the fluorescence variation intensity observed upon addition of ligands, F is the initial fluorescence intensity measured without ligand, ΔF/F max corresponds to the maximum fluorescence change induced by ligand, and [L] is the ligand concentration. All measurements were performed a minimum of three times. Beier H. Gross H.J. Electrophoresis. 1987; 8: 93-99Crossref Scopus (3722) Google Scholar). N-terminal sequencing was carried out as described (35Schmid R. Bernhardt J. Antelmann H. Volker A. Mach H. Biochem. 1973; 56: 502-514Crossref PubMed Scopus (1945) Google Scholar) was used. The caiT gene ofE. coli was cloned into plasmid pT7-5 as described under “Experimental Procedures,” yielding plasmid pTcaiT. To facilitate immunological detection and purification of the gene product, a nucleotide sequence encoding the FLAG epitope and a His6tag was attached to the 3′-end of caiT, resulting in plasmid pTcaiTFH. Plasmid DNA was transformed into E. coli WG389. This strain lacks the Na+/proline transporter PutP as well as the transport systems ProP and ProU, which catalyze the uptake of proline and betaines in response to osmotic stress. All trials to delete the caiT gene from the genome of E. coliWG389 did not produce viable cells. Plasmid-derived caiT was expressed via the lac promoter, and Western blot analyses with monoclonal antibodies directed against the FLAG epitope or the His6 tag demonstrated the CaiT location in the membrane fraction of isopropyl-β-d-thiogalactopyranoside-induced cells (data not shown). To investigate CaiT function, uptake ofl-[methyl-14C]carnitine into intact cells of E. coli WG398 transformed with either plasmid pTcaiT or pT7-5 was analyzed by a rapid filtration assay. Cells containing plasmid pT7-5 without caiT showed no or only little uptake ofl-[methyl-14C]carnitine depending on the l-carnitine concentration used (∼0.3 nmol/min/mg of protein at 10 μml-[methyl-14C]carnitine). Expression of plasmid-encoded CaiT did not stimulate this uptake process independent on the presence or absence of an electrochemical H+ or Na+ gradient (data not shown). However, CaiT increasedl-[methyl-14C]carnitine transport into cells preloaded with unlabeled l-carnitine, an activity not observed with cells lacking CaiT (Fig.2). Thisl-carnitine/l-carnitine exchange (counterflow) was inhibited by reaction of CaiT with the sulfhydryl reagentN-ethylmaleimide (∼80% inhibition of the initial rate), whereas the ionophore carbonyl cyanidem-chlorophenylhydrazone did not affect counterflow. Besides preloading with l-carnitine, also preloading with γ-butyrobetaine stimulated uptake of externall-[methyl-14C]carnitine into cells containing CaiT (Fig. 2). In contrast, CaiT-containing cells preloaded with glycine betaine, choline, proline, ordl-γ-amino-β-hydroxybutyrate did not accumulatel-[methyl-14C]carnitine (data not shown). Finally, cells transformed with plasmid pTcaiTFH showed the same counterflow activity as cells expressing caiT from plasmid pTcaiT, indicating that the attachment of the FLAG epitope and a His6 tag to the C terminus does not significantly influence CaiT function (data not shown). To test whether CaiT is solely responsible for the observed transport activity, the corresponding gene was overexpressed via the T7 promoter of plasmid pTcaiTFH using strain BL21(DE3) pLysS. In initial studies, different detergents (lauryldimethylamine oxide, Triton X-100, octyl β-d-glucoside, decyl β-d-maltoside, and dodecyl β-d-maltoside; 1.5% (w/v) final detergent concentration) were tested for the ability to solubilize CaiTFH from the membrane fraction of this strain. The most efficient solubilization of CaiTFH (>80% of the transporter was solubilized as judged from Western blot analysis) and the lowest tendency for aggregate formation were achieved with dodecyl β-d-maltoside. Therefore, the latter detergent was used throughout the whole solubilization/purification procedure. Subsequent to solubilization, CaiTFH was purified by Ni2+chelate affinity chromatography as described under “Experimental Procedures.” SDS-PAGE analysis of the resulting peak fractions revealed a broad band with an apparent molecular mass of ∼40 kDa (Fig. 3 A). The protein of this band reacted with monoclonal antibodies directed against the His6 tag or the FLAG epitope (Fig. 3 B). A membrane potential (ΔΨ, interior negative) and desired ion gradients were imposed across the proteoliposome membrane by creating an outwardly directed K+ diffusion gradient in the presence of valinomycin and changing the ionic composition and/or pH of the dilution buffer. However, inwardly directed electrochemical H+ and Na+ gradients did not cause significant accumulation ofl-[methyl-14C]carnitine in proteoliposomes (data not shown). In contrast, uptake ofl-[methyl-14C]carnitine was observed upon preloading the proteoliposomes with unlabeledl-carnitine (l-carnitine counterflow) (Fig.4). Labeling of CaiTFH with the sulfhydryl reagent N-ethylmaleimide inhibited this transport process as observed for intact cells. In addition, proteoliposomes preloaded with d-carnitine, crotonobetaine, or γ-butyrobetaine were able to accumulate externall-[methyl-14C]carnitine, with initial rates similar to those observed with proteoliposomes preloaded with l-carnitine. Surfactant protein D (SP-D) gene-targeted mice develop severe pulmonary disease associated with emphysema, pulmonary lipidosis, and foamy macrophage infiltrations. To determine the potential reversibility of these abnormalities, transgenic mice were developed in which SP-D was conditionally replaced in the respiratory epithelium ofSP-D −/− mice. SP-D was not detected in the absence of doxycycline. Treatment with doxycycline after birth restored pulmonary SP-D concentrations and corrected pulmonary pathology at adulthood. When SP-D was replaced in adultSP-D −/− mice, alveolar SP-D was restored within 3 days, pulmonary lipid abnormalities were corrected, but emphysema persisted. In corrected adultSP-D −/− mice, loss of SP-D caused focal emphysema and pulmonary inflammation but did not cause phospholipid abnormalities characteristic of SP-D −/− mice. Thus, abnormalities in surfactant phospholipid homeostasis and alveolar macrophage abnormalities were readily corrected by restoration of SP-D. However, once established, emphysema was not reversed by SP-D. SP-D-dependent processes regulating surfactant lipid homeostasis were disassociated from those mediating emphysema. Whitsett J.A. Hartshorn K.L. Crouch E.C. Korfhagen T.R. J. Immunol. 2001; 167: 5868-5873Crossref PubMed Scopus (241) Google Scholar). Since SP-D-dependent abnormalities in lipid metabolism were established immediately following birth and continued postnatally, it has been unclear whether SP-D is required during lung morphogenesis or whether there is an ongoing requirement for SP-D for regulation of pulmonary surfactant metabolism in the adult lung. To further clarify the role of SP-D in pulmonary homeostasis, recombinant SP-D was conditionally expressed in respiratory epithelial cells under control of the Clara cell secretory protein (CCSP) promoter in SP-D −/− gene targeted mice in vivo. Abnormalities in surfactant lipid homeostasis and monocytic infiltrates were reversed by expression of SP-D in adultSP-D −/− mice. Reversal of complementation in adult SP-D −/− mice caused emphysema and alveolar infiltrates but did not perturb phospholipid homeostasis. Mice used in the experimental procedures were handled in accordance with approved protocols through the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee at Cincinnati Children's Hospital. All mice had been maintained in containment facilities. At the time of study, all mice appeared healthy and without evidence of infection. Sentinel mice in the colony were serologically negative for common murine pathogens. The 1.3-kb cDNA encoding recombinant rat SP-D (rSP-D), a generous gift from Dr. E. C. Crouch, Washington University, was inserted into theNotI site of (tetO)7-CMVplasmid (9Tichelaar J.W., Lu, W. Whitsett J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 11858-11864Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (276) Google Scholar). Restriction enzyme digestion and 5′ end sequencing confirmed the orientation of the insert. The transgene was microinjected into fertilized FVB/N oocytes by the Cincinnati Children's Hospital Transgenic Core facility. Founders were identified by two sets of transgene-specific PCR using upstream primer 5′-ATA GGA CCC CAA GGC AAA CCAG-3′ and downstream primer 5′-TGT TCT GTCT-TGT ACC TCT AGG-3′ in rSP-D and upstream primer 5′-CAC CGG GAC CGA TCC AGC-3′ in cytomegalovirus (CMV) promoter and downstream primer 5′-CAC CCC CCA GAA TAG AAT GAC AC-3′ in bovine growth hormone polymerase A. Several (tetO)7-rSP-D transgenic mouse lines were generated. Founder line 10 expressed rSP-D at levels similar to those in wild type mice after treatment with doxycycline and was therefore utilized for this study. Proteins were resolved on 10–20% SDS-Tris-glycine-polyacrylamide gels (NOVEX, San Diego, CA) and transferred to nitrocellulose membranes. Blots were blocked with 5% nonfat milk and incubated overnight at room temperature with rabbit anti-mouse SP-D antiserum diluted 1:5,000 in Tris-buffered saline with 0.1% Tween. Blots were washed with Tris-buffered saline/Tween and incubated with peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG antibody (Calbiochem). After washing, blots were developed with a chemiluminescence detection system (Amersham Biosciences). Generally, at least two to four mice from each genotype were analyzed, and representative results are shown. J. Respir. Crit. Care Med. 2000; 161: A42Google Scholar). BALF was performed as described above, and after lavage, lung tissue was homogenized in saline. Differences between genotypes and treatments were evaluated by analysis of variance Fisher analysis. Differences of p < 0.05 were considered significant. Mouse lungs (12 weeks old) were fixed at 25 cm of water pressure with 4% paraformaldehyde in phosphate-buffered saline and processed into paraffin blocks. Five-μm sections from each lobe were stained with hematoxylin and eosin. Immunostaining of transgenic rSP-D was performed in lung tissue using an avidin-biotin-peroxidase technique (Vectastain Elite ABC kit, Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA). Immunostaining was completely blocked by co-incubation with purified mouse SP-D. SP-D mRNA and protein were undetectable inSP-D −/− mice or in triple transgenic (CCSP-rtTA, (tetO)7-rSP-D,SP-D −/−) mice in the absence of doxycycline (Fig. 2 A, lane 1). Administration of doxycycline to adult mice for 2 weeks resulted in production of physiologic levels of the rat SP-D in lungs of triple transgenic mice (Fig. 2 A, compare lanes 5 and6). Thus, in triple transgenic (CCSP-rtTA, (tetO)7-rSP-D,SP-D −/−) mice, the only detectable SP-D was derived from the rat SP-D transgene. When maintained on doxycycline from birth, airspace size, alveolar macrophage morphology, and pulmonary SatPC pool sizes were not different from controlSP-D +/+ mice (Figs.3 and Fig. 4 B). In contrast, in the absence of doxycycline, pulmonary abnormalities characteristic ofSP-D −/− mice were readily apparent in the triple transgenic mice (Fig. 3 and Fig. 4 A). In the absence of doxycycline, the severity of emphysema, macrophage abnormalities, and lipid accumulations was not distinguishable from that inSP-D −/− mice. Increased SatPC, foamy macrophage infiltrates, and emphysema characteristic of SP-D deficiency were observed. Pulmonary phospholipid content was decreased within 3 days and normalized 7–14 days after treatment with doxycycline (Fig. 5). Again, rSP-D was undetectable in the absence of doxycycline and was rapidly induced, reaching physiologic levels 3 days after administration of doxycycline (Fig. 2 B). Abnormalities in alveolar macrophage morphology were also readily reversed by restoration of SP-D in the adult mice (Fig. 6 C). To further assess the reversibility of airspace remodeling, triple transgenic mice that were maintained without doxycycline until 2 months of age were treated with doxycycline for 1–3 months. The thin arrow points to neutrophil infiltration. * indicates enlarged alveolar space.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) To assess the timing and extent of reversibility of the effects of SP-D, triple transgenic mice were maintained on doxycycline until adulthood and then removed from doxycycline. SP-D content in BALF decreased rapidly, being undetectable 3 days after removal from doxycycline as assessed by Western blot analysis (Fig.2 B). As assessed by immunohistochemistry, the intensity and extent of SP-D staining decreased rapidly, although residual SP-D staining was detected in rare subsets of cells 2 weeks after removal from doxycycline (Fig. 4 G). In the presence of doxycycline, SP-D staining was detected in alveolar type II cells in the alveolar parenchyma and in subsets of Clara cells lining the conducting airways (Fig. 4 F). Foamy alveolar macrophages, typical of SP-D deficiency, were observed within 2 weeks after removal from doxycycline (Fig. 4 C). Four weeks after removal from doxycycline, extensive infiltration by enlarged alveolar macrophages and airspace abnormalities consistent with emphysema were observed throughout the lungs (Fig. 4 D). Surprisingly, after removal from doxycycline for up to 4 weeks, SatPC remained at levels typical of wild type mice (Fig. 5). In the present study, rat recombinant SP-D was expressed at physiological levels. Conditional expression of recombinant rat SP-D completely corrected pulmonary abnormalities inSP-D −/− mice when expressed from birth. In adult SP-D −/− mice, extinction of the transgene expression resulted in a rapid decrease in alveolar SP-D, consistent with the known clearance rate of SP-D (14Ikegami M. Whitsett J.A. Jobe A.H. Ross G.F. Fisher J. Korfhagen T. Am. J. Physiol. 2000; 279: L468-L476Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and the pharmacodynamics of doxycycline on which reversal of transgene expression was dependent (15Perl A-K.T. Tichelaar J.W. Whitsett J.A. Transgenic Res. 2002; 11: 21-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar). In complemented adultSP-D −/− mice treated with doxycycline from birth, removal from doxycycline resulted in decreased tissue SP-D, reappearance of abnormal alveolar macrophage infiltrates, and airspace remodeling that were detected within 7–14 days. In contrast, SatPC was not reversed by loss of SP-D in adult mice. Thus, SP-D-dependent lung remodeling was neither dependent on lipid accumulation nor on processes that affect lung morphogenesis. Although surfactant pool size and alveolar macrophage abnormalities inSP-D −/− mice were readily reversed by restoration of SP-D, emphysema persisted, demonstrating that irreversible changes in lung parenchyma had occurred in the absence of SP-D. Lack of SP-D results in rapid onset of alveolar macrophage activation and initiation of tissue remodeling in adult animals. Thus, SP-D is required for maintenance of pulmonary homeostasis in the mature and developing mouse lung. The finding that replacement of SP-D corrected phospholipid and alveolar macrophage abnormalities but did not correct emphysema is of considerable clinical interest. Emphysema can be caused by both developmental and inflammatory processes, leading to the loss of lung parenchyma reflected by airspace enlargement. D. Massaro and G. D. Massaro (16Massaro D. Massaro G.D. Am. J. Physiol. 2002; 282: L345-L358Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar) recently summarized findings in rodent models wherein emphysema was partially reversible. In the present study, replacement of SP-D for 1–3 months did not correct established emphysema in theSP-D −/− mice. Such findings are consistent with clinical observations demonstrating that various forms of pulmonary hypoplasia and emphysema do not resolve. Therefore, despite the rapid correction of lipid surfactant and macrophage abnormalities by expression of SP-D, emphysema persisted. This conditional system will be of use in identifying agents that may enhance alveolarization. It has been unclear whether alveolar macrophage infiltration and emphysema in SP-D −/− mice are secondary to lipid accumulation or are mediated by distinct pathological mechanisms. In the present study, macrophage infiltrates and remodeling were observed after removal of the corrected mice from doxycycline. In sharp contrast, lung SatPC remained at normal wild type levels after prolonged removal from doxycycline and absence of SP-D. Thus, these experiments dissociate abnormalities in surfactant homeostasis from the airway remodeling. A similar dissociation of these two processes was observed in studies in which the SP-D mutant protein (Rr-SP-Dser-15/ser-20) caused a dose-dependent inhibitory effect on SP-D function, producing airspace but not lipid abnormalities in SP-D +/+ mice (17Zhang L. Ikegami M. Crouch E.C. Korfhagen T.R. Whitsett J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 19214-19219Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). Likewise, expression of a chimeric protein consisting of the neck and carbohydrate recognition domain of conglutinin linked to the SP-D amino-terminal and collagenous domain corrected surfactant phospholipid homeostasis but did not improve emphysema or macrophage activation in the SP-D −/− mice (18Zhang L. Hartshorn K.L. Crouch E.C. Ikegami M. Whitsett J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 22453-22459Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). Taken together, both structural and temporal requirements for the correction of pulmonary surfactant abnormalities are distinct from those mediating alveolar macrophage activation and tissue remodeling, suggesting that these two processes are mediated by distinct mechanisms in vivo. Furthermore, the finding that surfactant SatPC remained normalized in adult mice despite a prolonged absence of SP-D suggests that SP-D plays a critical role in establishing SatPC concentrations during postnatal development. Since lung SatPC pools are markedly higher in neonatal mice than in adults (6Wert S.E. Yoshida M. LeVine A.M. Ikegami M. Jones T. Ross G.R. Fisher J.H. Korfhagen T.R. Whitsett J.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 5972-5977Crossref PubMed Scopus (362) Google Scholar, 14Ikegami M. Whitsett J.A. Jobe A.H. Ross G.F. Fisher J. Korfhagen T. Am. J. Physiol. 2000; 279: L468-L476Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), SP-D appears to be required for the establishment of the low SatPC pool size characteristic of mature mice. Once normal SatPC concentrations were established in the complemented SP-D −/− mice, loss of SP-D in adulthood did not cause the abnormal accumulation of surfactant lipid. Therefore, SP-D is not required for maintenance of steady state SatPC pools in adult mice. The sites and level of expression of rSP-D in the present studies were virtually identical to those of the endogenous mouse and human SP-D protein (3Madsen J. Kliem A. Tornoe I. Skjodt K. Koch C. Holmskov U. J. Immunol. 2000; 164: 5866-5870Crossref PubMed Scopus (312) Google Scholar, 19Wong C.J. Akiyama J. Allen L. Hawgood S. Pediatr. Res. 1996; 39: 930-937Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar), the transgene being expressed in type II epithelial cells and bronchiolar epithelial cells in the lung. As demonstrated previously by Fisher et al. (20Fisher J.H. Sheftelyevich V., Ho, Y-S. Fligiel S. McCormack F.X. Korfhagen T.R. Whitsett J.A. Ikegami M. Am. J. Physiol. 2000; 278: L365-L373Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), rat recombinant SP-D fully corrected pulmonary abnormalities in theSP-D −/− mice and did not cause observable pulmonary abnormalities in wild type mice. Thus, the effects of SP-D deficiency on lung physiology are not related to the effects of SP-D in other organs but are dependent on local pulmonary requirements for SP-D. In the present study, the rat CCSP promoter was utilized to express the transgene. Although CCSP is normally expressed only in conducting airways in the mouse, this rat CCSPpromoter element expresses transgenes in both bronchiolar and alveolar epithelial cells, sites consistent with the known expression pattern of SP-D in the mouse (21Stripp B.R. Sawaya P.L. Luse D.S. Wikenheiser K.A. Wert S.E. Huffman J.A. Lattier D.L. Singh G. Katyal S.L. Whitsett J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 14703-14712Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The sites and extent of expression of SP-D observed in the present study are also consistent with previous studies with the CCSP-rtTA mice from this laboratory (15Perl A-K.T. Tichelaar J.W. Whitsett J.A. Transgenic Res. 2002; 11: 21-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar). The lack of detectable expression in the absence of doxycycline has made theCCSP-rtTA activator line highly useful for conditional expression of genes in vivo (9Tichelaar J.W., Lu, W. Whitsett J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 11858-11864Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (276) Google Scholar, 15Perl A-K.T. Tichelaar J.W. Whitsett J.A. Transgenic Res. 2002; 11: 21-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar). The time course of SP-D expression following administration or removal from doxycycline is consistent with previous studies in which luciferase activity was used to monitor of gene expression in SP-C-rtTA andCCSP-rtTA transgenic mice. Gene expression was induced within 6–12 h following addition of doxycycline to drinking water or food, and activity was generally decreased within 12–24 h after removal of doxycycline (15Perl A-K.T. Tichelaar J.W. Whitsett J.A. Transgenic Res. 2002; 11: 21-29Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar). Thus, the rapid loss of SP-D protein from BALF following removal of doxycycline is consistent with the known pharmacodynamics of doxycycline, the stability of rtTA, and the half-life of SP-D protein in the lung, the latter being approximately 8 h in the mouse (14Ikegami M. Whitsett J.A. Jobe A.H. Ross G.F. Fisher J. Korfhagen T. Am. J. Physiol. 2000; 279: L468-L476Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The distinct temporal differences for reversibility of macrophage abnormalities, as compared with surfactant phospholipid concentrations, suggest that these aspects of pulmonary homeostasis are influenced by distinct pathways.

RNA editing by members of the ADAR (adenosine deaminase that acts on RNA) enzyme family involves hydrolytic deamination of adenosine to inosine within the context of a double-stranded pre-mRNA substrate. Editing of the human GluR-B transcript is catalyzed by the enzyme ADAR2 at the Q/R and R/G sites. We have established a minimal RNA substrate for editing based on the R/G site and have characterized the interaction of ADAR2 with this RNA by gel shift, kinetic, and cross-linking analyses. Gel shift analysis revealed that two complexes are formed on the RNA as protein concentration is increased; the ADAR monomers can be cross-linked to one another in an RNA-dependent fashion. We performed a detailed kinetic study of the editing reaction; the data from this study are consistent with a reaction scheme in which formation of an ADAR2·RNA ternary complex is required for efficient RNA editing and in which formation of this complex is rate determining. These observations suggest that RNA adenosine deaminases function as homodimers on their RNA substrates and may partially explain regulation of RNA editing in these systems. The mechanism of action of ADAR2 on its RNA substrates is unclear. Little is known about the mechanism of RNA binding or substrate activation for the deamination event. To study the molecular basis for RNA recognition and adenosine deamination by members of the ADAR family, we have undertaken a series of studies involving hADAR2a using the R/G site of the human GluR-B pre-mRNA as a model system. We have characterized this minimal system using kinetic, gel shift, and cross-linking analyses. Interestingly, we have found that a ternary complex involving the association of two ADAR2 monomers with the RNA substrate is responsible for editing activity. Furthermore, the monomers can be cross-linked to one another in an RNA-dependent fashion, suggesting intimate association on the substrate. An analysis of RNA binding and R/G site editing using two deletion mutants indicates that association of ADAR2 with the editing site in a 1:1 complex is insufficient to yield efficient A to I editing. These results combined with previous observations suggest that editing of pre-mRNAs by members of the ADAR class of enzymes is contingent on homo- or hetero-dimerization on the RNA substrate and that this requirement is central to the regulation of editing by these enzymes.DISCUSSIONWe have carried out a detailed kinetic study of RNA editing by a member of the ADAR enzyme class using an RNA that closely resembles the R/G editing site in the GluR-B pre-mRNA. Substrate inhibition of editing, as determined by measurement of initial rates, is consistent with a kinetic model (Scheme A) in which the formation of a ternary enzyme-substrate complex (ESE) is required for efficient editing. As substrate concentration increases, free enzyme is sequestered in the ES complex and is unavailable to form the active ESE complex. Under this scheme, E+S⇌KSES→Ek1ESE→fastEPE SCHEMEA V0=k1[E]2[S]TKS+[E]Equation 5 the linear dependence of initial rate on enzyme concentration suggests that ES rapidly reaches equilibrium and that formation of the ESE complex is rate-limiting. When the concentration of enzyme is much higher than substrate, the initial rate (Vo) is given by Equation 5; the linear dependence of initial rate on total enzyme concentration is clear under conditions where [E] is much greater than Ks. Finally, we found a strong correlation between our kinetic analysis and Scheme A; we calculated the rate constant (k1) for formation of ESE under conditions of excess substrate or excess enzyme and obtained very similar values of 0.20 ± 0.04 pm−1s−1 and 0.21 ± 0.01 pm−1s−1, respectively.It is possible that the association of a second ADAR2 protein with the RNA is independent of the first binding event and that the second event represents binding of the target adenosine to the enzyme active site with no participation of the other monomer. Several pieces of evidence argue against these suggestions. First, chemical and enzymatic footprinting of both ADAR2 complexes have shown that the first binding event corresponds to protection of the editing site with an extended footprint observed at higher protein concentrations (31Ohman M. Kallman A.M. Bass B.L. RNA. 2000; 6: 687-697Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar). Second, we deleted distal regions of the R/G substrate, preserving the sequence proximal to the editing site, and observed a dramatic reduction in editing efficiency. Thus, initial binding of ADAR2 corresponds to protein-RNA association in the vicinity of the editing site, but the editing reaction itself requires association of a second ADAR2 monomer with the RNA substrate. It is unclear whether the chemistry of deamination is associated with the active site of the first or second monomer.Gel filtration and glycerol gradient sedimentation experiments performed with another member of the ADAR family of enzymes, ADAR1, indicated that ADAR1 exists as a monomer in solution (32Kim U. Garner T.L. Sanford T. Spiecher D. Murray J.M. Nishakura K. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 13480-13489Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Hough and Bass (33Hough R.F. Bass B.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 9933-9939Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) reported that partially purifiedXenopus ADAR1 formed complexes of ∼215 kDa (consistent with dimer formation) but behaved as monomers when fully purified. The presence of RNA in the partially purified protein preparation would explain these results. Cross-linking experiments with the bifunctional reagent DMS show that there is an intimate association between ADAR2 monomers on the R/G RNA and also that this association is RNA-dependent (Fig. 4).Comparison of the ADAR class of enzymes with related enzymes suggests that dimerization may be conserved as a functional requirement. Relatively little is known regarding the catalysis of A to I deamination within the context of double-stranded RNA, but it has been assumed that the chemical mechanism is related to that of the adenosine and cytidine nucleotide deaminases (34Carter C.W. Biochemie. 1995; 77: 92-98Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). In both classes of enzymes an active site zinc, coordinated by cysteine or histidine residues, serves to activate water for attack on the purine or pyrimidine base. Sequence comparisons show relatively little homology between the ADAR family active sites and those of other deaminases with the exception of the presence, identity, and relative arrangement of the putative zinc coordinating signature residues; mutagenesis of these residues in ADAR1 supports their roles in catalysis. Interestingly, the identity and arrangement of the signature residues in the ADAR family is more reminiscent of the cytidine deaminases than of the adenosine deaminases. In the cytidine deaminases, zinc is coordinated by His, Cys, and Cys whereas coordination in the adenosine deaminases involves three Cys residues. Additionally, both the cytidine deaminases and ADAR enzymes contain the His-Ala-Glu triad; the acid residue likely acts as a proton donor and acceptor during the course of catalysis. The adenosine deaminases function as monomers, but many cytidine deaminases including Escherichia coli cytidine deaminase (35Betts L. Xiang S. Short S.A. Wolfenden R. Carter Jr., C.W. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 235: 635-656Crossref PubMed Scopus (336) Google Scholar), the T4 bacteriophage cytidine deaminase (36Maley G.F. Duceman B.W. Wang A.M. Martinez J. Maley F. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 47-51Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and the apoB mRNA editing deaminase (37Lau P.P. Zhu H.J. Baldini A. Charnsangavej C. Chan L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 8522-8526Crossref PubMed Scopus (135) Google Scholar) function as dimeric or polymeric species. The x-ray structure of the E. coli cytidine deaminase dimer shows that the active site is partially formed by contributions from each monomer (35Betts L. Xiang S. Short S.A. Wolfenden R. Carter Jr., C.W. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 235: 635-656Crossref PubMed Scopus (336) Google Scholar).Recently, a class of tRNA-specific adenosine deaminases has been characterized by Gerber and Keller (38Gerber A.P. Keller W. Science. 1999; 286: 1146-1149Crossref PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar, 39Gerber A.P. Keller W. Trends Biochem. Sci. 2001; : 376-384Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). Members of the ADAT (adenosine deaminases that act on tRNA) enzyme family share sequence homology in editing domains with both the cytidine deaminases and members of the ADAR family; it has been suggested that ADAT enzymes evolved into the ADAR class by the acquisition of double-stranded RNA binding domains. The fact that tad2p (ADAT2) and tad3p (ADAT3) form heterodimers supports the observation that ADAR2 functions as a dimeric species.The enzymatic activity of the RNA-dependent protein kinase PKR has been shown to depend on dimer formation, although the mechanism of dimerization is the subject of controversy (40Wu S. Kaufman R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 1291-1296Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar). The sequence of PKR includes two N-terminal double-stranded RNA binding domains and a C-terminal catalytic domain and is thus reminiscent of the domain structure of ADAR2. Future experiments with ADAR2 will involve the localization of the dimerization interface within the protein sequence.Dimerization of ADAR2 on RNA may influence the editing activity of the enzyme in several ways. For example, the binding of a second ADAR2 monomer on its substrate may effect a conformational change in one or both monomers that is required for editing. Results from tryptophan quenching experiments are consistent with ADAR2 undergoing a conformational change upon the binding of RNA (41Yi-Brunozzi H.Y. Stephens O.M. Beal P.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 37827-37833Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). An additional piece of evidence supporting the need for a conformational change in ADAR2 before editing is the observation that a potent inhibitor of adenosine deaminase, coformycin (K d ∼10−15m), does not inhibit the activity of members of the ADAR family (15Kim U. Wang Y. Sanford T. Zeng Y. Nishikura K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 11457-11461Crossref PubMed Scopus (365) Google Scholar). Recently, Nishikura and coworkers (42Chen C.X. Cho D.S. Wang Q. Lai F. Carter K.C. Nishikura K. RNA. 2000; 6: 755-767Crossref PubMed Scopus (361) Google Scholar) have demonstrated that the mixing of ADAR3 with either ADAR1 or ADAR2 attenuated the editing activity of the latter two enzymes, whereas mixing ADAR1 and ADAR2 lowered the site selectivity of the A to I editing activity; in light of the data reported here, we interpret these observations to indicate that members of the ADAR family can form hetero- as well as homodimers on RNA substrates. The requirement of ADAR dimerization for editing as well as the modulation of activity by heterodimer formation are no doubt intimately involved in the regulation of the activity of these enzymes, including the site-specificity of editing.
